snippet.title: [K-UNESCO Adventures] EP.1 Tugging rituals and games
snippet.description:
Creators take off to explore UNESCO heritage in Korea!

Squid Game contestant 276, actor Lagahit Christian, 
and 33 other creators traveled to the Dangjin Gijishi Tugging Rituals and Games Festival 
to experience the UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage of Tugging Rituals and Games. 

Watch the video to see what it was like!

#KUNESCOADVENTURES #KOCIS #UNESCO

snippet.title: [K-UNESCO Adventures] Tour Sketch#1 Tugging rituals and games
snippet.description:
Explore UNESCO Heritage in Korea!

This is a tour to explore UNESCO cultural heritage sites in Korea, with various people from many countries who living in Korea.

This time, we went to Dangjin to experience Gijisi Tugging rituals and games festival, an intangible cultural heritage.

#KUNESCOADVENTURES #KOCIS #UNESCO

snippet.title: [KOCIS x Korea Reomit] Ep.1 Finding out how Indonesian friends learn Korea in Indonesia ü§î
snippet.description:
Hello everyone! üôåüèª

üéÅ We present you the VOD you have all been waiting for! 

In collaboration with Jang Hansol of Korea Reomit, 
we bring you the first episode, ‚ÄòFinding out how Indonesian friends learn Korea in Indonesia‚Äô. 

Through this video, we can see that Korean culture is truly alive and thriving in Indonesia! ‚ú®

As Korean culture is gaining more and more popularity,
 it seems that many Indonesians are becoming interested in learning Korean! 

In episode 1, 
we are joined by Bora-ssaem, who is currently teaching Korean, 
as well as one of our own K-influencers! 

Please check out episode 1 with Korea Reomit! ü§üüèª
We hope you enjoy üòò

#korea #korean #indonesia #indonesian #koreareomit #janghansol #kinfluencer 
 #honoraryreporter #language_learning #borassam #kocis #korean_#korea_selatan 
#bahasa_Korea #jakarta 

==================================================
KOCIS x Korea Reomit is a collaboration VOD series with 
one of the most popular influencers in Indonesia, Hansol Jang. 

In this series, 
Hansol conveys the differences and similarities of Korean and Indonesian culture 
and how Korean culture has been settling down in Indonesia. 

Please ‚ÄòSubscribe‚Äô and turn on ‚ÄòNotifications‚Äô!

snippet.title: [KOCIS x Korea Reomit] Ep.2 Korean food in Korea vs Indonesia üë®üèª üç≥
snippet.description:
Hello everyone! ü§ó

In our second episode, 
Jang Hansol explores how Korean food and dining culture has taken place in Indonesia üç≥
He visits two restaurants, and gains insight into how Indonesians enjoy Korean food.

As Korean culture is becoming increasingly popular in Indonesia 
with the influence of K-pop, K-dramas, and more, 
Indonesian people are also becoming increasingly curious about Korean food! 

However, as Indonesia is majority Muslim, 
it‚Äôs crucial that businesses must serve food that is halal, 
and it‚Äôs interesting to see how Korean food is adapted to be halal. 

Please check out episode 2 with Korea Reomit!
We hope you enjoy üòç

One more thing! 
Click on the link below to watch the 1st episode if you have missed it!  üòâ
1st Episode: https://youtu.be/Q5DHSLyh7KY

snippet.description:
Hello everyone! ü§ó
We are back with the third episode of KOCIS X Korea Reomit! 

In episode 3, 
Jang Hansol invites our Indonesian K-influencers 
to learn how to make a popular Korean dish, Bulgogi.

As you can tell from the video, 
making Bulgogi is quite simple, and not very difficult at all! 
And since it‚Äôs made from beef, it‚Äôs completely halal too, 
so no need to worry about that if you are religious üòâ

Episode 3 was shot while our K-influencers were fasting,

Through this video,

We hope it encourages everyone who watches this to try cooking Korean food at home as well! ü•¢

snippet.title: XODIAC unmasks the Mask Dance of Hahoe üé∂ | KO-WORKERS | Ep.16 Hahoe Byeolsingut Tallori
snippet.description:
Hello Everyone!
We present to you the 16th episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS üôåüèª

In today‚Äôs episode our KO-WORKERS, WAIN and BEOMSOO from XODIAC, are joined with Koreanet reporter, Margareth. Watch as they explore the world of Korea‚Äôs traditional mask dance of Hahoe!

Byeolsingut is a Korean ritual held every 3 to 4 years 
to pray for peace and prosperity of the village ‚òÆÔ∏è
It features a play in which performers use colorful masks 
and costumes to tell stories from comedy to drama.
It is now considered one of Korea‚Äôs Intangible Cultural Heritage üëçüèª

üéÅWe also have a special GIVEAWAY event for you!
If you would like to get a hand decorated mask by WAIN and BEOMSOO,

The two most liked comments on the video will be the lucky winners! 

Tune in to watch XODIAC wolf and seal duo, WAIN and BEOMSOO, 
and Koreanet reporter Margareth 
to explore the colorful Korean dance of Hahoe Byeolsingut Tallori!

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Traditional PaperüìÉ| Ep.10 Hanji
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!ü§é

We present to you the 10th episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS! üë®üèª‚Äçü§ù‚Äçüë®üèª

In our 10th episode, Irene goes to Goesan, a city that is located in the Chungcheongbuk-do region of Korea. She travels there to experience the process of creating Hanji, the traditional paper of Korea!üìÉ

Irene‚Äôs KO-Worker for the day is Ahn Chi Yong, the Hanji master. Irene experiences the full package, starting off with removing weeds around the mulberry bushes. Mulberry is the key ingredient to creating Hanji. Therefore, it‚Äôs necessary to remove the weeds to eliminate competition for nutrients, allowing the mulberry to grow! The bark is then removed in order to create Hanji. Then from the bark, impurities must be removed, then pounded with on a stone board. Irene had quite some difficulties with the next step, where the fiber is dissolved in water and the layers of paper are skimmed out with a paper mold and blind. Lastly, the process is complete after the paper is dried thoroughly. 

Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of creating Hanji, taught by the master himself. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicariously through Irene. 

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 10 of KO-WORKERS!

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Ornamental Knifeüî™‚ú®| Ep.9 Jangdo
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!ü§é

We present to you the 9th episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS! üë´

In our 9th episode, Irene goes to Gwangyang, a city that is located in the southwestern region of Korea. She really does travel far and wide each time to learn more about jobs that are unique to Korea!

Irene‚Äôs KO-Worker for the day is Park Jong Goon, who is the master of the Korean traditional ornamental knife, Jangdo.üî™‚ú®
The process of creating an ornamental knife is very different from those of the previous jobs. It‚Äôs a delicate process that requires precision as well as resilience since it involves forging metals. First step is to forge the silver by heating and hammering it repeatedly until it becomes the right width and thickness, in order to create the silver decorations. Once the decorations, including the chrysanthemum flowers, are finished, the hilt and scabbard must be created. The blade is created by forging iron at 1400 degrees Celsius. The blade and hilt are then attached using heated pine resin. The steps involving fire made quite an impression on Irene!

Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of jangdo, taught by the master himself. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicariously through Irene. 

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 9 of KO-WORKERS!

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Traditional Korean Knotsüßµ| Ep.8 Maedeup
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!ü§é 

We present to you the 8th episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS!üë´

In our 8th episode, Irene goes to Changwon, which is a city located in Gyeongsangnam-do province. 
Irene‚Äôs KO-Worker for the day is Bae Soon Hwa, who is a master at Korean traditional knots, Maedeup.üßµüß∂
She had been doing this job every day since she was 17! The first part of the process requires dyeing silk yarn by soaking it in a blue pigment solution extracted from true indigo. Then using various equipment and techniques such as Kkeunmok (interweaving), it‚Äôs possible to create necklaces, bracelets, and so on using the knots. It seems that Irene is naturally gifted at this, as our Maedeup master points out. She follows complicated techniques without difficulty!
Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of Maedeup, taught by the master herself. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicariously through Irene. 

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 8 of KO-WORKERS!

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Traditional Korean Embossingüíñ| Ep.7 Jeon-gak
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!ü§é

We present to you the 7th episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS!üëÄ

In our 7th episode, Irene goes to Busan, a city that is located in the southeastern region of Korea. Wow, she really is travelling all over the country to meet our masters!üòé

Irene‚Äôs KO-Worker for the day is Ahn Jung Hwan, who is the master of Korean traditional embossing, jeon-gak. Although it may seem easier than previous jobs at first glance because there is no physical labour involved, it‚Äôs proved to be Irene‚Äôs most difficult job yet! It requires delicate skills and precision, something that cannot be learnt so easily! Jeon-gak is used to create personalized signatures, which are used to sign legal documents and such. To start off, Irene learns the basics of calligraphy, and learns to smooth stone over sandpaper and carve letters. 

Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of jeon-gak, taught by the master himself. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicariously through Irene. 

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 7 of KO-WORKERS!

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Traditional Korean Spiritüç∂| Ep.6 Andong Soju
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!ü§é

We present to you the 6th episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS!üôè

In our 6th episode, Irene goes to Andong, a city in Gyeongsangbuk-do which is in the eastern region of Korea, slightly to the south. Here, she learns to create Andong soju in the traditional way. Back in episode 1, she created makgeolli, another type of traditional drink, so hopefully this time it will not be too hard for her!üòÇ

Irene‚Äôs KO-Workers for the day, Master Kim Yeon Bak and Baek Young Hwa, are masters of the traditional distilled liquor, Andong Soju.üç∂
They have been mastering the cultural art for 32 years now! The process of creating traditional Andong Soju is somewhat similar to makgeolli, but it has two additional processes since it requires distillation. First, Nuruk needs to be created in order to kickstart the fermentation process. This is done by mixing wheat and water! After 20 days, the Nuruk is crushed and mixed with steamed rice and water. Then it is stored and kept inside a pot for 20 more days! Then the pot is put over a fire, and the resulting steam is the final product, Andong Soju! Andong Soju‚Äôs alcohol content is 45 degrees, so it‚Äôs quite potent, but it‚Äôs known for its smoothness and lack of hangover the next day!

Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of producing Andong Soju the traditional way, taught by the masters themselves. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicariously through Irene.ü•∞

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 6 of KO-WORKERS!

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Traditional Salt Farmüåä| Ep.5 Sea Salt Farm ‚ÄúYeomjeon‚Äù
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üñê 

We present to you the 5th episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS!üë®üèª‚Äçü§ù‚Äçüë®üèª

In our 5th episode, Irene goes to Taean-gun, in Chungcheongnam-do. which is located on the west coast of Korea. Being from a coastal city herself, Irene recognizes the scent of the sea, which is familiar to her.ü§çüíô

Irene‚Äôs KO-Worker for the day, Master Jeong Gap Hoon, is a master and connoisseur of traditional salt farming. He has been producing salt in the traditional method for over 40 years now! Our Master‚Äôs world revolves around the art of making salt and it‚Äôs rumored that customers who get a taste of his salt can‚Äôt go back to consuming other salt! The source of the salt is seawater, which naturally stores and flows into the salt farms. After a process of evaporation and purification, saltwater of over 25% salinity is considered ready for preparation. The crystalized sea salt is raked up and shoveled. Once the salt is collected and drained, it is taken to be dried and filtered. Excess moisture in the salt is removed, then it is ready to be filtered. This process is done with the help of aged pine pollen, which filters out the dust and lowers sodium chloride levels, resulting in a delicious Cheonilyeom (pure sun-dried salt). After all this, the salt is filled in sacks of 20kg each, ready to be consumed.üåû

Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of producing salt the traditional way, taught by the master himself. It‚Äôs real hard work for Irene. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicariously through Irene. 

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 5 of KO-WORKERS! 
=========================================
KO-WORKERS is a show where you can get a vicarious experience of jobs unique to Korea! 

For a day, you get to learn about a job and start working, participating in various processes and learning new skills.

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Onggi Masterüëç| Ep.4 Traditional Earthenware "Onggi"
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!‚ú®

We present to you the 4th episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS! üëÄ

In our 4th episode, Irene goes down south to the city of Sangju, in Gyeongsangbuk-do! She is met with a familiar view of pots scattered across the yard. However this time, she will be creating not the food stored inside them, but the pots themselves. Irene will experience the traditional method of creating onggi (traditional earthenware) for a day!üî•

Irene‚Äôs KO-Worker for the day, Master Dae-hee Jeong, is a master of onggi crafting, a skill that was designated as an intangible cultural asset. Onggi is where food and all sorts of other items were stored in the past, especially fermented foods. The traditional and ancient methods which have been around for thousands of years are disappearing, which is why the government designated these skills as an intangible cultural asset. First, high quality clay is produced by mixing different soils. Second, the onggi is shaped, with charcoal placed in the center. Then once the onggis are air dried, they are glazed with lye, a fermented mix of pine wood ashes and yakto. This process is very important in order to create an onggi that breathes, so that it can store food for a long time. Lastly, the onggi is placed in a kiln, which is fired up to high temperatures, reaching 1200 degrees celcius. 

Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of making traditional Korean earthenware Onggi, taught by the master himself. It‚Äôs real hard work for Irene and the others. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicariously through Irene.ü§é

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 4 of KO-WORKERS!

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Keeping Traditions Aliveü™î| Ep.3 Traditional Fermented Sauce
snippet.description:
Hello everyone! 

We present to you the 3rd episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS!üë´

In our 3rd episode, Irene goes down all the way to the South of the Jeolla-do in Damyang-gun to meet the 35th Korean Food Grand Master, Ki Soon Do, who has been continuing a 370 year old tradition of making fermented sauce! Nowadays, traditional methods of making Korean sauce cannot be easily found, but Irene will experience the traditional method for a day!üå∂

Traditional fermented sauce, as our grand master puts it, can be seen as the root of Korean food culture and there are multiple steps to producing traditional fermented sauce. First, the ‚Äòmeju‚Äô beans which will be used to make the sauce must be rinsed thou roughly, and then boiled. They must be rinsed properly as well as getting rid of small stones that may have slipped in! The beans are then boiled for 4 hours, and rested for another 2 hours. In order for them to ferment properly, they must be cooked well. After the beans are cooked well, they are pounded and then shaped into a rectangle. Then they are tied with straw in order to be hung. Although this may look easy, it requires skills! Then the meju is hung in order to go through the fermentation process. After 30 days of hanging and fermenting, the meju is cleaned and stored in a crock along with water, peppers, charcoal and dates. This is left for 70 to 80 days!üåû

Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of producing traditional Korean paste, taught by the master herself. The resulting paste is delicious, and as mentioned earlier, the root of Korean cuisine. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicarously through Irene.üíñ

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 3 of KO-WORKERS!

snippet.title: [KO-WORKERS] Crimson Red Dyeüé® | Ep.2 Hongyeom Dye
snippet.description:
Hello everyone! 

We present to you the second episode of our original VOD series, KO-WORKERS!üë´

In our second episode, Irene visits the Hongyeom Master in Jongno-gu, Seoul to work for a day!ü•Ä Hongyeom refers to the process of dyeing fabrics crimson and it‚Äôs recognized as the Intangible Cultural Asset No.49 of Seoul.‚ú®

In the past, the color red was considered a royal color and was only found among the upper classes or the royal palace. Producing these dyes is difficult work, and requires a lot of effort and patience. It goes through various processes such as extracting yellow pigment, extracting red pigment which is done by producing lye. 

The colors can be extracted from various dyes, but safflowers are the main representative color sources. The lye is naturally produced by pouring water on ash made of burnt bean stalks. The safflower dye produces yellow and red, and the lye helps extract the red color. This alkaline liquid is then neutralized with the acidic omija berry vinegar, mixed to develop the perfect result, and the most stunning color: crimson. Finally, the patterned fabric is dyed. The fabric used here is soaked in water before dyeing, and is called Doryo mundan, which was used by the upper class in the Joseon Dynasty. 

Join Irene as she works her way through the entire process of traditionally creating a dye, taught by the Hongyeom Master himself. The resulting color is called Daehong (ÎåÄÌôç) which is a beautiful crimson. We hope this episode is informative and that you get a chance to experience these traditional jobs vicarously through Irene. 

Thank you, and we hope you enjoy Episode 2 of KO-WORKERS!

snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíö

We present you the 29th episode of the HAYIK SHOW!üéß

In Episode 29, we are joined by our K-influencer guests Justin Van Rivera from the Philippines and Rizka Amalia Sampurno from Indonesia!üòÜ

They talk about their various experiences in Korea, 
so don‚Äôt miss out!üßê

Every K-influencer has unique experiences in Korea, 
so it truly is interesting to hear their stories and experiences.

Today‚Äôs topic will be about Korea‚Äôs superconductor.üß™
A superconductor is a material that achieves superconductivity, which is essentially a state of matter that has no electrical resistance. Recently, Korean scientists found a way to create the first superconductor that works in room temperature! This became a huge leap in the world of science!üëÄ

Now, tune in to listen to our hosts and guests talk about this magnificent scientific discovery that happened in Korea!

Today‚Äôs topic will be about the Korean Chilseok Story.üíû
Chilseok, also known as the seventh evening, is a Korean traditional festival which falls on the seventh day of the seventh month. Its a traditional folk tale story about a heavenly kings weaver daughter named Jicknyeo, and a Cow herder named Gyeonwoo.üåïüåâ

There are different festivities that Koreans do during Chilseok, listen to our hosts and guests talk about it in today‚Äôs episode!

snippet.title: [New Wave Busan] A wave in Parisüóº | Ep.28 Cafe de Busan
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 28th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 28, Esther & Jennifer are going to reopen one of the pop-up zones for the promotional campaign in Paris, France that was held from June 20 to June 21 called the ‚ÄòBusan Dabang‚Äô!‚òï

One of the events held for the World EXPO 2030 Busan bid on-site in Paris was the ‚ÄòCafe de Busan‚Äô. This was a pop up store that was opened in Paris which held several events that would provide the Korean culture experience!üóº

Today our hosts are in-theme with ‚ÄòCafe de Busan‚Äô and will reopen ‚ÄòCafe de Busan‚Äô by doing activities that were held there!ü•∞

snippet.title: [New Wave Busan] ‚ú®A Wave of Funüåä| Ep.27 Busan Sea Festival
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 27th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 27, Micah & Jennifer are visiting the Busan Sea Festival.üéä

The Busan Sea festival is a festival that has been deep rooted in the traditions of Busan. It was first held in 1996 to promote Busan as a beautiful harbor city. Originally meant as a way to bring in more people to Busan, the festival is now considered to be one of the must-go-to festivals in Korea.

The festival takes place in the 5 main beaches of Busan; Haundae, Gwanganli, Songo, Dadaepo. and Songjeong Beach. Each of the beaches have different themes and cultural events. The hands-on programs are tailored to suit every age group and is definitely worthwhile. With a grand opening ceremony and cultural performances, the Busan Sea festival is a guaranteed wave of fun!üòÜ

Check out Episode 27 and get to visit the Busan Sea Festival.

snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 25th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 25, Micah & Jennifer are visiting the Oryukdo, located in Busan.üèù

Oryukdo Islands refers to a cluster of rocky bodied Islands locatedin the Southern Coast of Busan.

The name is a combination of the Korean number ‚ÄòO‚Äô meaning 5 and
‚ÄòYuk‚Äô meaning 6, which refers to the number of Islands you can see
depending on the tides. One of Oryukdo‚Äòs greatest attractions is the Skywalk.‚òÅ

Just as it name indicates, the Skywalk is a bridge made of glass that stands 35 meter high off a cliff, looking down on crashing waters.

Watch Micah and Jennifer explore the beauty of nature known as Oryukdo.
Check out Episode 25 and get to visit Oryukdo.üå¥

snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 24th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 24, Micah & Jennifer are visiting the Museum of Contemporary Art Busanüé®

The Museum of Contemporary Art Busan (MOCA Busan)is a public museum focuses on contemporary art.
Its main aim is to introduce a new trend in arts, while considering the issue of nature and ecosystem as a priority.üí´

Located on the beautiful island of Eulsukdo,
the Museum of Contemporary Art Busan finished its construction in 2017.
It spans 29,900m2 of land and intertwines modernism and environment in its architecture and its works. 

Check out Episode 24 and get to visit the Museum of Contemporary Art Busan.

snippet.title: [New Wave Busan] Terrariums in BEXCOüéâ| Ep.23 Busan Youth Fair
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 23rd episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 23, Micah & Jennifer are visiting the Busan Youth Fair, 
held in BEXCO, Busan.üéä

The Youth High Fair is an event suporting the World Expo 2030 Busan. 
Until the 20th of July, Busan Youth Fair is available for everyone,
and is the perfect opportunity to try out fun activities!üî•

Located in the Exhibition Center 1 Hall 2B of BEXCO, 
the Busan Youth Fair is a convention with several fun booths. 
Each booth has unique themes and special activities!üòé

Each stall is packed with dynamic activities such as:
- making terrariums 
- pressing dry flowers
- receiving personal color analysis
- experiencing VR
- competing against each other, ‚ÄòPhysical 100‚Äô style!

Check out Episode 23 and get to visit the 2023 Busan Youth Fair hosted in Bexco by Cheongchun High!‚úà

snippet.title: [New Wave Busan] Standing with World Leadersüëç | Ep.22 APEC Nurimaru House
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 22nd episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 22, Micah and Jennifer are visiting the Nurimaru APEC House located near the Haeundae Beach. 

The Nurimaru APEC House is a combination of the Korean word 
Nuri (‚ÄúWorld‚Äô) and Maru (‚ÄùSummit‚Äú), which in combination means 
‚ÄùA house where the world summit gather together for the APEC meeting". 

Located in the fortified Dongbaekseom Island, 
the Nurimaru House has become a memorial hall 
that representents the summit that was held in those halls. 

The Nurimaru APEC House is a beautiful spot 
that morphs tradition, beauty, and modernism, 
making it a perfect spot for people who want a spectacular view üëè

Check out Episode 22 and get to tour the extravagant conference hall of 
Nurimaru APEC House!üåç

snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 21st episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 21, Micah and Jennifer are creating a new landmark designs for the BIADW Theme, ‚ÄòSense of Place‚Äô.‚ú®

The Busan Architectural Design Workshop, was first held in 2003, 
and has been an annual workshop for architects all around the world. 

Mark your calendars because this year, 
because the workshop is being held online from July 3rd till the 20th. 

This year the workshop will allow participants to propose the Redevelopment Project Site. 
Join us today as Micah and Jennifer try design own unique landmarks for this proposal.

Will this be their new career path? 
Watch now to find out!üòé

Check out Episode 21 and get to know more about the 
Busan International Architectural Design Workshop.üåç

snippet.title: [New Wave Busan] Rainbow city of Korea?! üåà| Ep.20 Gamcheon Culture Village
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 20th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 20, Micah and Jennifer explore the Gamcheon Cultural Village. üåà

Home of cultural events, the Gamcheon Cultural Village is located near the modern landmarks of Haundae, Gwangan Bridge, and Centum City. üéÜ

Nicknamed the ‚ÄúMachu Pichu of Busan‚Äù this village is formed by several colorful houses built in a lego-like staircase-fashion on a coastal mountain, making it the epitome of beauty and chaos. 

Make sure you visit when you get the chance, as the photo booths, 
restaurants, and cultural events is a guaranteed fun spot for your next trip. 
Who knows? You might even be able to take a picture with the little prince!üòÄ

snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 18th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 18, Micah and Jennifer visit Eulsukdo. 
A beautiful island that is located between the Nakdong River and the South Sea. 

It‚Äôs especially known to be a sanctuary for migratory birds. 
Micah and Jennifer visit the Busan Wildlife Medical Center, which cares for injured animals before they are released back into the wild. üß∏

They meet many different animals there that are being treated, especially birds. 
Eulsukdo was also the first stop of the BIE during their trip to Busan.üíï

Check out Episode 18 to learn more and explore with Micah and Jennifer!

We present to you the 17th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 17, Micah and Jennifer explore the World Climate Industry EXPO, which was held at BEXCO, an exhibition and convention center in Busan. 

The World Climate Industry EXPO is a venue of international discussions 
that are connected to the main themes of the World Expo 2030 Busan. 
It discusses introducing carbon neutral solutions and technologies 
to combat the global climate crisis. 

The exhibition includes

snippet.title: [New Wave Busan] Old Port Rebornüåù| Ep.16 Northport Waterfront Park
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 16th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 16, Micah and Jennifer explore the Busan North Port Waterfront Park. Formerly known as Busan‚Äôs North Port, or Bukhang.

The North Port area was off-limits to citizens, 
however, the area is being transformed, for the World Expo 2030. 
It will become an entirely new and technologically advanced space 
for the citizens and tourists of Busan.

It‚Äôs also eco-friendly, which fits perfectly with the theme of Busan‚Äôs bid for the World Expo 2030,  ‚ÄúTransforming Our World, Navigating Toward a Better Future‚Äù. 

In Episode 16, Micah and Jennifer are joined by the cute mascot Boogi, who is super excited!ü•∞

Check out Episode 16 to learn more about the World Expo 2030 Busan!

snippet.title: [New Wave Busan] Ready, Set, Fireüèπ| Ep.26 Sajikjeong, Archery
snippet.description:
Hello everyone!üíô

We present to you the 26th episode of our original VOD series 'New Wave Busan'!üåä

In Episode 26, Micah & Jennifer are visiting the Sajikjeong, located in Busan. 

There are 4 archery fields in Busan. And the 29th Korea National Archery Association Talent Contest was held to support the World EXPO 2030 Busan bid here in the Archery Ground on July 16th.

The Sajikjeong is an archery stadium which holds various competition such as the aforementioned 29th Korea National Archery Association Contrest. Today we are joined by our long awaited friend Boogi, the official mascot of Busan, to try learn the amazing sport of Archery. üèπ

Check out Episode 26 and get to visit Sajikjeong, Archery Stadium.

#talktalkkorea2022  #ttk2022  #kocis  #koreatravel

snippet.title: [Talk Talk Korea] 2022 KOCIS Invitation Tour Part.1
snippet.description:
K-Influencers, Honorary Reporters, and Talk Talk Korea winners 

who continued to excel as KOCIS' Korean culture ambassadors 

were invited to Korea to celebrate in 2022.


Despite the differences in countries and languages, 

everyone had a lot of fun on the 9-day trip to Korea 

with people who have the same passion for Korea! 

Let's meet them in the video!

#talktalkkorea2022 #ttk2022 #KOCIS #koreatravel

snippet.title: 2022 K-wave Festival to attract 7K foreign promoters of Korean culture
snippet.description:
The 2022 K-wave Festival, which honors and shares content on Korea made by foreign creators with Hallyu fans worldwide, was held on Dec. 10 with great success.

An estimated 252,865 Hallyu fans around the globe watched the event live on Korea.net's YouTube channel.

The Korean Culture and Information Service (KOCIS), an affiliate of the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism, hosted the festival at Exhibition Hall 2 of the Korea International Exhibition Center, aka KINTEX, in Goyang, Gyeonggi-do Province.

At this year's event, prizes went to the top 10 Honorary Reporters and top eight K-influencer teams comprising nine members for their activities to promote Korean culture. Talk Talk Korea, a KOCIS-sponsored international online contest of Korea-related content, also announced this year's grand prize and other winners in all eight themes.

Through creation of Korean cultural content in a variety of ways, the winners reflected on the past year and described their experiences of introducing Korea to the world.

snippet.title: [2022 K-wave Festival Recap] Awards Ceremony Part 3. Talk Talk Korea
snippet.description:
#Korea #Hallyu #Festival #Global #KOCIS #koreanet #talktalkkorea2022 

2022 K-wave Festival ‚ÄúGateway to Korea‚Äù was able to end in great success thanks to your warm support and love. 

The purpose of this year‚Äôs awards ceremony was to look back and appreciate the works of the 2022 Global Korean Culture Ambassadors. 

Talk Talk Korea is the world‚Äôs largest online contest for Hallyu content, and under the theme of ‚ÄúWhat I love about Korea‚Äù, it received 46,362 pieces from 154 countries around the world this year, setting a record for the most amount of submissions. 

Winners of the 2022 Talk Talk Korea:  
‚ñ∂ What I  'DESCRIBE' about Korea :  Angel Daniel Granados Gurrola / Mexico 
‚ñ∂ What I 'LISTEN TO' about Korea : Anastasiia Troshkina (NEW GENERATION) / Ukraine 
‚ñ∂ What I 'WRITE' about Korea : Kholod Elsayed Muhammad Elshahaly / Egypt 
‚ñ∂ What I 'LOVE' about Korea : Laura De la Portilla  Fern√°ndez (Only One) / Cuba 
‚ñ∂ What I 'ENJOY' about Korea : Glenn Besorio Tiondo & Prince Loyd Besorio / Philippines
‚ñ∂ What I 'DRAW' about Korea : Tri Iva Fitriani / Indonesia 
‚ñ∂ What I 'DISCOVER' about Korea : Troa Ova Fotroamo (Mindeulle) / Hungary 
‚ñ∂ What I 'EXPERIENCE' about Korea : Alejandra Daniela Penayo / Argentina

For those who missed the ceremony or those who‚Äôd like to relive the memories, watch the clip!
==============
Don‚Äôt forget to like, subscribe, and hit the notification bell!

snippet.title: [KOREA IS] International City Busan | Ep.8 Global Events üåä
snippet.description:
#2030Î∂ÄÏÇ∞ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ∞ïÎûåÌöå #Korea #BUSAN #Travel #Koreais #koreanet  #globalevent

Hello everyone! 
We are here to present our new original VOD series [KOREA IS] that conveys Korea‚Äôs various features that led Korea to earn its global presence today. 

The final episode is about the International City of Korea, Busan. 

Busan is the second largest city and number trading hub in Korea. Global events including the APEC conference, Busan International Film Festival, and Busan International Fireworks Festival, as well as various marine-related festivals, are held throughout the year. 

Busan is a city that represents freedom, and it is an open-minded city that contributes to unifying the world with its openness. In other words, Busan is the optimal place to realize the World Expo's value of moving humanity forward. The 2030 World Expo is a national event that will serve as an opportunity to demonstrate Korea's strengths not only in its advanced technologies but also in its cultural assets. 

We are presenting the 8th episode in support of the successful hosting of the World Expo in Busan and many other global cultural events in the future! 

The 8th Episode Features: 
Hatago Priebe / Namibia 
Thomas Lecart / Belgium

Hello everyone! 
We are here to present our new original VOD series [KOREA IS] that conveys Korea‚Äôs various features that led Korea to earn its global presence today. 

The 6th episode is about Sports in Korea! 

Korea‚Äôs biggest contribution to the world of sports is absolutely Taekwondo. It is the most significant Korean sport and features some of the most artistic moves in the worlds of martial arts. However, Taekwondo nowadays has rather been modernized, which makes the sport more entertaining and approachable. 

The collaboration of K-POP and Taekwondo! The mixture of two great Korean cultures is just fascinating, and the performances are truly overwhelming. Click on the video if you are curious about what this ‚Äúperformance‚Äù is!

We are here to present our new original VOD series 'KOREA IS' that conveys Korea‚Äôs various features that led Korea to earn its global presence today.

snippet.title: The journey of ¬°Hola! Caravana K-Culture | Documentary
snippet.description:
Hola!! ‚ú® 

Do you remember the "¬° Hola! Caravana K-Culture", who toured four Central American countries in August to promote Korean culture?

A documentary featuring the journey of the "¬°Hola! Caravana K-Culture" was aired on MBC NET at 10 a.m. on December 16th

Here's the story of "¬° Hola! Caravana K-Culture", who performed in Central  American countries without Korean Cultural Center!

Here is the full story of their journey
We hope you enjoy it
==============
¬°Hola! Caravana K-Culture is composed of 10 Korean artists who are selected through a competitive audition at the Korea National University of Arts, Korea‚Äôs top art school. ‚ú®

These prestigious artists of Korea toured four Central American countries to demonstrate wonderful street performances using Korean instruments to present cultural and artistic street performances. 
==============

snippet.title: [Talk Talk Korea] 2022 KOCIS Invitation Tour Part.1
snippet.description:
K-Influencers, Honorary Reporters, and Talk Talk Korea winners 

who continued to excel as KOCIS' Korean culture ambassadors 

were invited to Korea to celebrate in 2022.


Despite the differences in countries and languages, 

everyone had a lot of fun on the 9-day trip to Korea 

with people who have the same passion for Korea! 

Let's meet them in the video!

snippet.title: [Talk Talk Korea 2022] Talk Talk School üè´ 7th Class Calligraphy | Ep.7 Calligrapher Lee Jeong Hwa
snippet.description:
#talktalkkorea2022 #ttk2022 #talktalkschool #Calligraphy

Want to participate in the Talk Talk Korea Contest, but don't know how to participate?

Talk Talk School will teach you how to create a work for your participation in the contest.

Webtoon? Calligraphy? Traditional Game? Photography? Music Video? Travel? Story? Dance? If you learn at Talk Talk School, you can become a winner of Talk Talk Korea too!

How about participating in the calligraphy category of Talk Talk Korea 2022 after watching the Calligraphy Class taught by the Calligrapher Lee Jeong Hwa on Talk Talk School ep 07?

‚ñ° Hangeul Calligraphy (Handwriting)

Create your own calligraphy with the theme of Hangeul.
